question_1.question: What is the first step when configuring read access to an Azure SQL Database according to the provided text?

options.option_a: Run a script in SSMS to create a user from an external provider
options.option_b: Deploy the security tab in TimeXtender
options.option_c: Give admin privileges to the user making the initial changes
options.option_d: Set the user as the Azure Active Directory admin

question_1.explanation: The first step is to give admin privileges to the user making the initial changes, as stated in the text.

question_2.question: How do you assign an Azure Active Directory user as the admin for an Azure SQL Database?

options.option_a: Run the CREATE USER script in SSMS
options.option_b: In the Azure portal, set your user as the admin using the 'Set admin' option
options.option_c: Deploy the security tab in TimeXtender
options.option_d: Add the user manually in the TimeXtender desktop application

question_2.explanation: To set a user as the admin, you use the 'Set admin' option in the Azure portal, as described in the text.

question_3.question: Which tool is used to run a script that grants read access to all tables in an Azure SQL Database?
question_3.explanation: The script to grant read access is run in SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS), according to the instructions.

question_4.question: In the TimeXtender desktop application, how do you provide users in a group access to only valid schemas?

options.option_a: Run the CREATE USER script with the valid schema
options.option_b: Use the 'Set admin' option in the Azure portal
options.option_c: Right click Database Roles > Object Security Setup > Click on Schemas and check user Access Role
options.option_d: Deploy the security tab without any modifications

question_4.explanation: To provide access to valid schemas, you right click Database Roles, go to Object Security Setup, click on Schemas, and check user Access Role, as per the process outlined.
